abstract:
In order to effectively prioritize areas for habitat restoration and protection in the Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP), we need to understand the current conditions of the fish communities in the streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) reservation. To accomplish this, we will develop a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of fish populations and collect baseline data sets for use in EDT model development.

The Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model is an analytical framework used to evaluate habitat conditions and determine which areas are most likely to benefit from restoration efforts. It relies on empirical observations, local expert knowledge, and other models and analyses to identify priority reaches and habitat attributes for improving fish performance. While the EDT model requires ratings of Level II attributes, we place the highest confidence in data that is based on empirical evidence.

However, we have found that fish community data is limited for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, especially smaller streams. In order to address this, we will develop a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of fish populations. This protocol will be consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP), to ensure consistency and comparability across studies.

We will collect baseline data on the fish communities using methods such as electrofishing, trap netting, and visual surveys. Sample sizes will be large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings. This information will be used to inform habitat restoration and protection priorities and to track changes in fish populations over time.

By implementing a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of fish populations and collecting baseline data sets for use in EDT model development, we can ensure that our habitat restoration efforts are effective and prioritized based on the current conditions of the fish communities in the streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes reservation. This will help us to address the shortcomings identified during the 2011 evaluation, including the lack of statistical rigor in monitoring study design and unclear prioritization of habitat restoration actions.

description:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) aimed to enhance the survival of migratory rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) reservation through habitat restoration and riparian corridor rehabilitation. In evaluating the project's accomplishments during the Northwest Power and Conservation Committees Categorical Review process, it was identified that prioritization of habitat restoration actions and monitoring study design lacked clarity and statistical rigor (LeCaire and Peone 1991).

To address these shortcomings, LRHIP developed a new approach to stream habitat restoration and protection, focusing on restoring natural stream function. This strategy utilizes an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model for determining the highest priority areas for habitat restoration and protection (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). EDT is an analytical model that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models to evaluate which reaches and habitat attributes are most likely to have the greatest benefit for improving fish performance.

EDT model development requires rating Level II attributes for current conditions, with the highest confidence given to attribute ratings based on empirical data. Several Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow, but there are also fish attributes. Limited fish community data is available for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly in smaller streams (Bouwes et al. 2011; Terraqua Inc. 2009).

To collect baseline information on the fish communities and allow for future monitoring consistency with other programs such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) and Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP), LRHIP established a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of fish populations. This included using consistent sampling methods, minimum sample sizes for high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings, and standardized data collection and analysis techniques.
